Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Racial discrimination. An appeals court rejected a jury's award of $1.3 million in punitive damanges but upheld $332,309 in actual damages plus $20,447 in legal fees.
Private Litigation Case Title: Hunley v. Sprint United Mgt Co
Info Source: Hunley v. Sprint United Mgmt. Co., 21 Fed. Appx. 532

Description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau filed proposed orders in federal courts against Sprint and Verizon which, if approved, would provide $120 million in redress to wireless customers said to have been illegally billed hundreds of millions of dollars in unauthorized third-party charges. The CFPB alleges that the companies operated billing systems that allowed third parties to "cram" unauthorized charges on customers' mobile-phone accounts and ignored complaints about the charges.

Mobile service provider Sprint agreed to pay $2.95 million in civil penalties to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that the company failed to give proper notice to consumers who were placed in a program for customers with lower credit scores and charged an extra monthly fee.
back pay award in unfair labor practices case
Info Source: Extracted from an NLRB dataset covering 1999-2011 downloaded at https://catalog.data.gov/dataset/nlrb-cats-final-c-case-data-bulk-19990101-20110930-in-xml

Description: The Federal Communications Commission's Enforcement Bureau announced that Verizon Wireless agreed to pay $90  million and Sprint Corporation agreed to pay $68 million to settle investigations that revealed the companies billed customers millions of dollars in unauthorized third-party premium text messaging services, a practice called cramming.

Sprint Corporation agreed to pay $7.5 million to resolve an FCC Enforcement Bureau investigation of the mobile wireless company's failure to honor consumer requests to opt out of phone and text marketing communications.

The Federal Communications Commission's Enforcement Bureau reached settlements totaling $1.4 million with Hamilton Relay, InnoCaption, and Sprint Corp., resolving investigations into the companies' inability to handle 911 calls through applications used by callers who are hard of hearing.
Sprint Corporation agreed to pay the United States $5,565,250 to settle claims that it defrauded the General Services Administration from 2000 to 2002.

Sprint Corporation and AT&T Corp. agreed to pay $1.125 million and $365,000, respectively, to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that they failed to notify certain applicants for telephone service of their rights under federal credit laws.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php

Description: back pay award in unfair labor practices case
Info Source: Extracted from an NLRB dataset covering 1999-2011 downloaded at https://catalog.data.gov/dataset/nlrb-cats-final-c-case-data-bulk-19990101-20110930-in-xml

Description: T-Mobile agreed to fully refund its customers for unwanted third-party charges it placed on their phone bills, a practice known as mobile cramming, paying at least $90 million to settle a Federal Trade Commission lawsuit.

The FCC's Enforcement Bureau announced that T-Mobile would pay a fine and provide benefits to consumers totaling at least $48 million as part of a settlement resolving an investigation into whether the company adequately disclosed speed and data restrictions for its "unlimited" data plan subscribers.

The Federal Communications Commission's Enforcement Bureau reached a $17.5 million settlement with T-Mobile, resolving an investigation into two 911 service outages that occurred on the company's national network in 2014.
back pay award in unfair labor practices case
Info Source: Extracted from a spreadsheet obtained from the NLRB through a Freedom of Information Act request fulfilled on 5/16/2017.

Description: The FCC Enforcement Bureau and T-Mobile USA, Inc. entered into a Consent Decree as part of a global settlement totaling at least $90,000,000 in payments and restitution to consumers.  This Consent Decree resolved allegations that T-Mobile charged consumers for third-party products and services that the consumers did not authorize, a practice that is more commonly known as cramming.
T-Mobile was fined $819,000 for failing to provide the minimum number of hearing aid-compatible handset models required under the rules during calendar years 2009 and 2010.

The U.S. Department of Labor reached an agreement with T-Mobile USA, Inc. to pay 20,546 workers at 13 call centers around the country $4,779,985 in back wages as a result of alleged violations of the overtime provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA).
Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division

Description: back pay award in unfair labor practices case
Info Source: Extracted from an NLRB dataset covering 1999-2011 downloaded at https://catalog.data.gov/dataset/nlrb-cats-final-c-case-data-bulk-19990101-20110930-in-xml

Description: Sprint Communications, Inc., formerly Sprint Nextel Corporation, agreed to pay the government $15.5 million to resolve allegations it defrauded federal law enforcement agencies when recovering its costs of carrying out court-ordered wiretaps, pen registers, and trap devices.
tower registration

Info Source: Contained in data obtained on August 17, 2017 in response to an open records request.
Contained in data obtained on August 17, 2017 in response to an open records request.

Description: The Federal Communications Commission reached a settlement concluding its investigation into whether T-Mobile USA, Inc. violated the Communications Act when it failed to correct ongoing problems with delivery of calls to rural consumers and whether it violated the FCC rule that prohibits providers from inserting false ring tones with respect to hundreds of millions of calls.  T-Mobile agreed to pay $40 million to the U.S. Treasury and entered into a compliance plan to prevent future violations.
overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Samuel Rubio v. Sprint Corporation et al
Nora Salamanca v. Sprint/United Management Company

Description: overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Guilbaud et al v. Sprint Nextel Corporation et al; Smith v. Sprint/United Management Company

Court: New York Supreme Court for New York County
Private Litigation Case Title: PALMA, KAREN vs. METROPCS WIRELESS, INC.

Private Litigation Case Title: Palma et al v. Metro PCS Wireless, Inc.

overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Amber Anderson, et al. v.?Nextel?Retail Stores LLC, et al.

Description: overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Bruner v. Sprint/United Management Company et al; Lipnick et al v. Sprint United Management Company et al; Almonte v. Nextel of New York Incorporated

Description: Although the cash settlement was $4 million, the court estimated that other changes Sprint agreed to make brought the total value to at least $25 million.
Private Litigation Case Title: In re Sprint Corporation ERISA Litigation

Description: Sprint agreed to pay $22 million to settle multistate litigation concerning uncashed rebate checks.

AT&T, MCI Worldcom and Sprint agreed to pay a total of $1.5 million to settle multistate litigation alleging they misled customers on long-distance calling rates. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the amount was divided evenly among them.

Info Source: McCollum Reaches Settlement with Sprint Over 'Free' Ringtones, Targeted News Service, October 8, 2010 (via Nexis).

Description: The New York Attorney General announced a $330 million settlement of a False Claims Act lawsuit filed against cellphone company Sprint alleging that for nearly a decade it knowingly failed to collect and remit more than $100 million in state and local sales taxes owed on its flat-rate wireless calling plans sold to New Yorkers.

The New York State Attorney General announced agreements with Verizon, Time Warner Cable, and Sprint to shut down major sources of online child pornography. The three companies agreed to pay a total of $1.125 million to fund additional efforts by the Attorney General's office and the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children to remove child pornography from the Internet.  The announcement did not specify how that amount would be divided among the companies. Here we assume it was split evenly among them.
Sprint agreed to pay $2.4 million in settlement of allegations it switched consumers to Sprint long-distance telephone services without permission, a practice known as slamming.

Sprint agreed to pay $1.2 million in cash and donated calling cards in settlement of allegations it switched customers' long distance service from another carrier to Sprint without full knowledge or approval.

Sprint Corporation agreed to pay $12 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it billed customers millions of dollars in unauthorized third-party premium text messaging services, a practice called cramming.  This was part of a larger $68 million settlement involving the Federal Communications Commission; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-sprint-corp-0

Verizon Wireless, Cingular Wireless, and Sprint PCS agreed to pay a total of $5 million to settle multistate litigation alleging misleading advertisements and unclear disclosures relating to service agreement terms and wireless coverage areas. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among them.

T-Mobile agreed to pay $18 million to resolve multistate litigation alleging that the company billed customers millions of dollars for unauthorized third-party subscriptions and premium text messaging services. This was part of a larger $90 million settlement involving the Federal Communications Commission; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-t-mobile-usa-inc-0

Info Source: Attorney General Reaches Settlement Agreement with T-Mobile Over Third Party Charges, Targeted News Service, July 19, 2010 (via Nexis).

Description: deceptive advertising

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs

Description: Sprint Nextel Corp. agreed to pay New York City $295,000 to settle a lawsuit in which the Department of Consumer Affairs accused the cellular telephone provider of misleading consumers with deceptive advertisements.
Agency: New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection
Info Source: Sprint Nextel pays $295,000 to settle NYC suit for deceptive ads, Associated Press, April 18, 2006 (via Nexis).

Description: T-Mobile USA Inc. paid New York City $135,000 to settle a lawsuit in which the Department of Consumer Affairs accused the cellular telephone provider of misleading consumers with deceptive advertisements.
Agency: New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection
Info Source: T-Mobile settles ad lawsuit, Newsday, December 15, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: Sprint agreed to pay $280,000 in settlement of allegations it did not give adequate notice of price increases and changes to service.
Agency: Wisconsin Department of Agriculture, Trade and Consumer Protection

Description: $20,000 fine levied for offering an illegal inducement to Washington consumers in which T-Mobile agreed to pay the outstanding cell phone balances of customers who switched to T-Mobile so long as they purchased T-Mobile's PDP Plus plan, thereby violating RCW 48.30.140; RCW 48.30.150(1)(c).
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Description: T-Mobile agreed to pay a $200 million penalty to resolve an investigation of its subsidiary Sprint's compliance with the Commission's rules regarding waste, fraud, and abuse in the Lifeline program for low-income consumers.

Description: The settlement resolves all issues in this proceeding regarding the Settling Respondents' involvement with the Malibu Canyon Fire in October of 2007.

Company: Assurance Wireless USA, (F/K/A Virgin Mobile USA, wholly owned by Sprint) (U-4327-C)
Description: Settlement between Sprint and CPED where Sprint failed to comply with federal non-usage rules by claiming reimbursement for discounts provided to CA LifeLine participants who should have been de-enrolled from the LifeLine Program between July 2017 to August 2019. Sprint agreed to deposit $34,684,170.70 to the Commission's Advance Collection Account which will be released to the CA LifeLine Program. Sprint was also ordered to remit an additional $7,002,760.60 for interest, and any potential benefits Sprint may have accrued due to overcollection resulting in a total settlement amount of $41,686,931.
Notes: The source provides only the year, so the date is listed here as January 1.
